newsitem.title: CANADA: CWB sees malt barley price up on China, S. America.
newsitem.headline: CWB sees malt barley price up on China, S. America.

text.p: Chinese and Latin American demand for western Canadian malting barley should raise prices in crop year 1996/97 (Aug/July), CWB market analyst Larry Sawatzky said.

"We raised our PRO (Pool Return Outlook) because of continued strong demand from Asia and South America, China in particular. China is our largest two-row malting barley export market," Sawatzky said.
Select Two-Row Canada Western Designated Barley PROs for August were revised up C$0.09 a bushel to the C$230-250 a tonne range from last month's C$226-246 a tonne range.
Reduced European exports of two-row barley and lower Australian sales in the last crop year allowed the CWB to make market share gains in Colombia and Brazil.
Chinese and Latin American maltsters buy two-row barley because it has a higher extraction rate than six-row, he said.
"Although the Chinese may be eating a little less of our bread, they're drinking a little more of our beer," he said.
Select Six-Row Canada Western Designated Barley PROs, however, were left unchanged Thursday at C$191-211 a tonne.
"The U.S. is our major market for six row. We're want to see what happens with the quality of their crop," he said.
